prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: UltraVISTA z > 3 Massive Galaxies Spectral Scan
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: These observations are for a spectral scan in Band 3 looking for CO emission lines to determine redshifts and gas masses for a photometrically-selected sample of dusty starbursting galaxies at 3 < z < 6.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The likely linewidth of our targets is 200-400 km/s. We aim for a velocity resolution of 150 km/s, to attain a high signal-to-noise ratio in each line. We request FDM mode with 1875 MHz of bandwidth. We will use 16x frequency binning to reduce the data load. The will result in a velocity resolution of 20 km/s. The data will then be binned to coarser velocity resolution, based on the precise linewidth and noise ratio of the source.

Our targets have a likely angular size of 0.5 - 1.0 arcseconds. We therefore request a resolution of 1.0 arcsecond, as we do not need to resolve the sources. We do not require complementary ACA observations.

Our sensitivity estimate is driven by our goal of detecting a range of CO lines at 3 < z < 6. We have estimated the CO line flux densities as follows. We have estimated the L_IR and star formation rates (SFRs) for each galaxy based on their photometric redshifts and 24um fluxes. These are all > 1000 M_sun/yr. We have based the following calculation on a conservative SFR estimate of 500 M_sun/yr for each galaxy, which is the lower-limit of all sources.
From a SFR we estimate a total H2 gas mass by assuming a constant molecular gas conversion time of 2 Gyr. We then estimate a flux density of CO(1-0) bu assuming a CO/H2 conversion factor of 3.5, suitable for star-forming objects at high-z (Tacconi et al. 2013). We extrapolate flux densities in the higher-J CO lines by assuming a spectral line energy distribution (SLED) typical for dusty galaxies at z ~ 2 (Bothwell et al. 2013).
Our requested rms (1.1 mJy per 150 km/s channel) will be sufficient to detect the faintest CO line in Band 3 at this redshift - CO(4-3) - at a significance of 5 sigma. Higher order CO lines will be detected at higher significance, up to 8 sigma. We stress this is a very conservative estimate based on a SFR of only 500 M_sun/yr. If the SFRs of the galaxies are higher, up to 5000 M_sun/yr, as implied by the L_IR, or else if they host a dusty AGN, then all CO lines will be detected at much higher significance, as high as S/N = 30.
This rms has been calculated assuming a 150km/s channel. Being a redshift-scan, our aim is simply to detect each line. We therefore choose a channel width closely matched to the likely line width of our sources (200-400 km/s).
We are aware that the S/N over 1/3 of the line width is 4 in the chart above. However, the overal S/N will be 5 (for the faintest line) because our science goals do not require us to kinematically resolve the lines: we aim to detect the position of the lines, which is best achieved by matching the channel width to the expected line width.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Major investments in photometric surveys over the last five years have revealed the surprising result that the most massive galaxies (Log(M/Mstar) > 11.2) in the universe assemble a significant amount of their stellar mass at very early times. Unlike their counterparts at z = 0, these massive galaxies at z > 3 appear to be extremely active, with almost all of them forming stars at 1000's of solar masses per year, and many hosting dust-obscured AGNs. While photometric redshifts confirm their existence, it is difficult to make more accurate measurements of other properties without spectroscopic redshifts. Unfortunately, these galaxies are far too faint for standard optical/NIR spectroscopy. ALMA has enormous potential to return the first spectroscopic redshifts of this population using CO lines. Here we propose to obtain spectroscopic redshifts for a mass-complete sample (Log(M/Mstar) > 11.2) of 18 massive dusty starbursting galaxies at 3 < z < 6 by scanning for CO lines in Band 3. This will be the first spectroscopic sample of its kind, and will allow us to determine robust stellar masses, dust extinctions, SFRs, and cold gas masses for this remarkable population.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge, University of
